questions.text: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his brother after trying to jump out of a moving car. He says that the state police have been following him for the last 7 months. He recently quit his job at a local consulting firm to work on his mission to rid the world of evil. He does not smoke, drink alcoholic beverages, or use illicit drugs. He takes no medications. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/86 mm Hg. On mental status examination, his response to the first question lasted 5 minutes without interruption. He switched topics a number of times and his speech was pressured. He spoke excessively about his plan to "bring absolute justice to the world". He has a labile effect. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. A toxicology screen is negative. He is admitted to the hospital for his symptoms and starts therapy. One week later, he develops difficulty walking and a tremor that improves with activity. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's latest symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dopamine antagonist. This patient's combination of delusions for at least 6 months, as well as his pressured and disorganized speech indicates schizophrenia. His current difficulty walking and tremor following treatment suggest that he has developed extrapyramidal symptoms. Dopamine 2 receptor antagonism is the main mechanism of action for antipsychotics, especially first-generation antipsychotics such as haloperidol. All antipsychotics that interact with the D2 receptor can cause extrapyramidal syndrome, but this effect is particularly pronounced in the use of first-generation antipsychotics due to their high affinity to D2 receptors. Patients who have taken antipsychotics on the scale of days to weeks can show parkinsonism, including tremors, rigidity, and shuffling gait, which the patient in the vignette has. Management of EPS symptoms can be treated with an anticholinergic (e.g., benztropine), a dopamine agonist (e.g., amantadine), and reducing or omitting the offending drug.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Dopamine agonists, such as ropinirole and pramipexole, may be used in the treatment of Parkinson’s disease (especially earlier disease). This class of medication should not be given to patients with psychosis since it further increases psychotic symptoms such as hallucinations. Option: B. Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) are used to treat major depressive disorder. They would neither be indicated for schizophrenia nor cause EPS symptoms such as this patient's pseudo-parkinsonism. Option: D. Central-acting anticholinergic agents such as atropine can cause the following symptoms: confusion, agitation, thirst, skin flushing, and reactive pupils. Benztropine, an anticholinergic agent, would neither be indicated for schizophrenia nor cause EPS symptoms such as this patient's pseudo-parkinsonism.

questions.text: A previously healthy 5-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of difficulty breathing and vomiting that began 1 hour after she took an amoxicillin tablet. She appears anxious. Her pulse is 140/min, respirations are 40/min, and her blood pressure is 72/39 mmHg. She has several well-circumscribed, raised, erythematous plaques scattered diffusely over her trunk and extremities. Pulmonary examination shows diffuse, bilateral wheezing. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Epinephrine The patient's acute hypotension, tachycardia, respiratory distress, and dermatologic findings in the setting of recent antibiotic use are consistent with anaphylaxis. Epinephrine should be administered immediately if anaphylaxis, a type I hypersensitivity reaction, is suspected. Epinephrine acts at both beta-adrenergic receptors (at lower doses) and alpha-adrenergic receptors (at higher doses) to help increase blood pressure, increase bronchodilation, reduce mucosal edema in the upper airway, and reduce the release of inflammatory mediators from mast cells and basophils.

Highyeild:

Action of Epinephrine Relaxes smooth muscle in the airways Counteracts histamine and other cytokines Raises blood sugar level Raises heart rate, blood pressure, and myocardial oxygen demand For Intramuscular injection of Epinephrine... Onset of effect: 3-5 min Duration of effect: 1-4 hours

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Norepinephrine causes vasoconstriction and increased inotropy via its effects on both alpha-1 adrenergic receptors and beta-1 adrenergic receptors. It is a second-line agent for anaphylaxis and not the best initial choice of therapy. Furthermore, it would not address this patient's respiratory distress. Option: C. Albuterol, a beta-2 receptor agonist, can be used as an adjunctive medication in the treatment of anaphylaxis to counteract the smooth muscle contraction that causes bronchospasm. However, it would not address the hypotension seen in this patient and is not the best initial treatment. Option: D. Glucocorticoids such as methylprednisolone are commonly given as an adjunctive treatment in anaphylaxis. However, glucocorticoids take several hours before the onset of action and would not address the acute hypotension and respiratory distress seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with gastroesophageal reflux disease comes to the physician because of severe burning chest pain and belching after meals. He has limited his caffeine intake and has been avoiding food close to bedtime. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows erythema and erosions in the distal esophagus. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the most appropriate drug for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inhibition of H+K+ ATPase. This patient has symptoms consistent with severe GERD, and evidence of reflux-induced esophagitis. A proton pump inhibitor (PPI) would be the appropriate first-line drug therapy for this patient. Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) irreversibly inhibit H+/K+ ATPase in parietal cells of the stomach and thus reduce the ATP-dependent secretion of H+ ions into the gastric lumen. They are considered first-line for patients with severe GERD.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. H2 antihistamines, such as ranitidine, inhibit histamine-dependent gastric acid secretion via their antagonistic effect on H2 receptors in the gastric parietal cells. Although they may be used for mild GERD symptoms, a different agent is indicated for this patient with severe symptoms and esophagitis. Option: C. Neutralization of gastric acid is the mechanism of action of antacids such as calcium carbonate. These agents are commonly used for mild, intermittent heartburn, and/or GERD. However, this patient has severe symptoms and is unlikely to experience long-term improvement with antacids alone. Option: D. Enhancement of the mucosal barrier in the stomach and duodenum is the mechanism of action of sucralfate, which forms a protective barrier, acts as an acid buffer, and promotes HCO3 production. It is commonly used in the treatment of peptic ulcer disease but is not considered first-line for GERD.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of myocardial infarction is admitted to the hospital for treatment of atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (173 lb). He is given an intravenous bolus of 150 mg of amiodarone. After 20 minutes, the amiodarone plasma concentration is 2.5 ?g/mL. Amiodarone distributes in the body within minutes, and its elimination half-life after intravenous administration is 30 days. Which of the following values is closest to the volume of distribution of the administered drug?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

60L The volume of distribution is the theoretical volume that would contain the total amount of the drug within the body at a concentration equal to that present in plasma.

Highyeild:

The volume of distribution (Vd) is calculated by dividing the total amount of the drug in the body by its concentration in the plasma. Since the half-life of amiodarone is extremely long, only a negligible amount of the drug would be eliminated from the body after 20 minutes, meaning that the total drug amount in the body after this time would approximately be equivalent to the amount of the drug administered. In this case, the total drug amount is 150 mg (150,000 μg) and the plasma concentration is 2.5 μg/mL. Therefore, Vd = 150,000/2.5 = 60,000 mL (60 L). The volume of distribution represents the tendency of a drug to be distributed in body tissue rather than plasma. Amiodarone has a high tissue distribution because it is greatly lipophilic.

questions.text: We have two patients. One requires suppression of emesis caused by an anticancer drug that causes a high incidence and severity of vomiting (highly emetogenic drug). Another patient has severe diabetic gastroparesis and gastroesophageal reflux, which requires relief. Which one drug would be suitable for both indications (assuming no specific contraindications)?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Metoclopramide Metoclopramide has clinically useful antiemetic and prokinetic actions and would be suitable for either of the patients described in the question. The antiemetic effect arises from the blockade of dopamine (and, probably, serotonin) receptors in the brain’s chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ). The drug is indicated for not only chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, but also that which may occur with radiation therapy, postoperatively, or in response to opioid analgesics or emetogenic toxins. The enhanced gastric and upper intestinal motility probably reflects an enhancement of the expected effects of ACh on muscarinic receptors found on the longitudinal smooth muscle in the GI tract. Metoclopramide raises the lower oesophageal sphincter tone and relaxes the pyloric sphincter, which hastens gastric emptying.

It can help with short-term diarrhea or irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), Crohn’s disease, ulcerative colitis, and short bowel Sx.
